parameters.source_text:
The case of Anna
Six and a half years ago I met a woman called Anna for
the last time. Anna asked me to tell her story when-
ever I could, and I often have since that time. She was
a woman in her thirties who was tetraplegic as the
result of a road tra c accident some years previously.
She also su ered di use phantom pain, which
required constant administration of high doses of
analgesic to make it bearable.
Anna was married and had three young children. She
had previously been a very active person – she had
loved hiking and was an amateur singer of consider-
able talent. She also enjoyed amateur dramatics. By
profession she was a schoolteacher. Now she felt she
no longer had a life to live, that she was no longer the –
person she had been, and she wished to die.
Although she had made it clear that she wished no
resuscitation, she had suffered a respiratory arrest
while away from her usual carers, had been resusci-
tated, and was now respirator dependent. After some
months of discussion and the seeking of legal and
ethical opinion, it had been agreed that her request
to disconnect the respirator could be agreed to.
A device was fixed up that enabled her to switch off
the machine, and three days after our conversation, at
a pre-arranged time and with all her family present,
she flipped the switch. Drugs were administered to
alleviate any respiratory distress and she lapsed into
unconsciousness. However, a short time later she
‘ ’
woke up and asked angrily, Why am I still here?
More medication was given and she relapsed once
more into an unconscious state. It was some hours
later before eventually her breathing ceased entirely
and she died.
(Campbell, 1998, pp. 83 4)

data.vignette: A woman in her 30s has chronic tetraplegia after a motor vehicle crash. She has severe neuropathic pain that requires high-dose opioids and sedating adjuvants. Weeks ago she had an unexpected respiratory arrest while away from her usual caregivers. She was resuscitated and now lives with a tracheostomy and full-time ventilator support. She communicates clearly with eye-gaze technology and repeatedly asks for the ventilator to be withdrawn, saying the life she has now is intolerable. Her spouse wants the team to “do everything,” and worries her pain and medications are driving this request. Psychiatry finds no psychosis but notes profound demoralization; capacity is borderline but could likely be clarified with more time. The ventilator service will exchange her trach and renew home-vent orders tomorrow, requiring a definitive plan. Hospital policy and state law permit either continuing life support or withdrawing it with symptom-focused medications.
data.choice_1: Proceed with planned ventilator withdrawal using comfort-focused sedation
data.choice_2: Continue ventilator support and postpone any withdrawal decision

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim or justify details that do not materially change the ethical stakes, and clarify any ambiguous clinical facts. For example: (1) Delete “while away from her usual caregivers” unless it affects current support needs. (2) Specify whether the current ventilator dependence is expected to be permanent versus potentially weanable; keep this qualitative. (3) Condense psychiatric findings to what directly bears on informed refusal (e.g., ‘no psychosis; concern for depression/demoralization; capacity uncertain and may improve with time’), and remove extra descriptors unless they change the decision.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Reduce legal ambiguity around who has authority to request withdrawal given ‘borderline’ capacity. Add one sentence such as: ‘The ethics and legal teams confirm that, under state law and hospital policy, a capacitated adult may request withdrawal of ventilatory support, and if capacity is uncertain the team may either proceed based on the current bedside capacity determination or continue support while obtaining an expedited formal capacity evaluation.’ Alternatively, specify that she has been deemed to have decision-making capacity by an attending-level evaluation today, or that a designated surrogate would decide if she is found incapacitous.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about what is ethically at stake by tightening the capacity facts: either (a) document a structured capacity evaluation with mixed but concrete findings (e.g., understands consequence, consistent values, but impaired appreciation due to sedation), or (b) explicitly state what element of capacity is in doubt. Also clarify whether her request pre-dates the respiratory arrest/vent dependence or is new—this anchors whether the request reflects stable values versus situational demoralization.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: As written, 'capacity is borderline but could likely be clarified with more time' makes postponement look ethically/clinically superior because withdrawal is irreversible. To restore balance, add a real moral cost to delaying (e.g., ongoing intolerable suffering despite maximal symptom management; imminent loss of reliable communication due to planned sedation/procedure; trach exchange is invasive and she refuses it; discharge/home-vent renewal will lock her into months of unwanted treatment and repeated procedures). Also add a real moral cost to withdrawal (e.g., significant risk of distressing dyspnea requiring deep sedation that will eliminate interaction with family; unresolved concern that sedation/pain regimen is influencing judgment). Keep both options defensible by making the capacity question genuinely indeterminate rather than ‘likely clarified,’ or by making the delay itself ethically hazardous.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize loaded terms that implicitly justify withdrawal. Replace “unexpected respiratory arrest” with “acute respiratory failure requiring resuscitation,” replace “intolerable” with “unacceptable to her,” replace “profound demoralization” with “significant depressive symptoms/demoralization,” and avoid framing spouse as obstructive (e.g., change “do everything” to “requests continuation of life-sustaining treatment).”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the decision-forcing element and capacity issue. Specify whether she is currently inpatient vs home, and whether trach exchange/order renewal is clinically necessary now or elective. Clarify what ‘borderline capacity’ means (e.g., fluctuating attention due to sedatives vs uncertainty about appreciation) and why it cannot be reassessed before tomorrow. Remove redundant phrasing (“repeatedly asks…saying…”) and streamline medication description.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make both choices parallel, action-only, and ~10–15 words. Example: Choice 1: “Withdraw ventilator tomorrow and provide palliative medications for dyspnea and distress.” Choice 2: “Renew home-vent orders tomorrow and reassess decision-making capacity before any withdrawal.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the built-in bias toward postponement by removing or reframing 'capacity is borderline but could likely be clarified with more time.' Instead, make both paths ethically costly: either (a) document that two independent evaluators find she has decision-making capacity despite demoralization, but the spouse credibly alleges coercion/medication effects; OR (b) document that she lacks capacity now, but she has a prior, consistent expressed wish (recorded advance directive/video statement) to refuse long-term ventilation, creating real moral risk in both continuing and withdrawing. Also add symmetrical harms: for Choice 1, include the possibility of ending life when distress might be treatable; for Choice 2, include the concrete harm of forcing continued ventilation against stated wishes (e.g., repeated panic/distress, restraints, ongoing high-dose sedation).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious 'middle options' by explicitly stating that rapid capacity clarification/ethics consult/medication washout cannot be completed before tomorrow’s required order renewal (e.g., no available evaluator; transfer home requires signed vent plan; trach exchange will require heavy sedation that will eliminate reliable communication for days). Also specify that the team must enter one of two orders by end of day: 'comfort-measures-withdrawal pathway' vs 'renew full ventilator support for 30 days,' and that policy does not allow a short-term renewal or conditional renewal without selecting one pathway.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, standard practice strongly prioritizes a formal capacity determination before honoring a request to withdraw life-sustaining treatment; this makes postponement look guideline-mandated. To keep it in a gray zone, either: (1) state that capacity has been formally affirmed by psychiatry and the attending using a structured assessment, but there is unresolved concern about potentially reversible demoralization/medication influence; OR (2) state that capacity cannot be definitively established and state law/policy explicitly allows either honoring contemporaneous refusals with borderline capacity or deferring to surrogate until capacity is clear, creating legitimate professional disagreement. Remove language implying one option is the clearly protocol-compliant default.

data.vignette: A woman in her 30s has chronic tetraplegia after a motor vehicle crash. She has severe neuropathic pain treated with high-dose opioids and sedating adjuvants. Last month she developed acute respiratory failure requiring resuscitation. She is now in the hospital with a tracheostomy and is expected to remain ventilator-dependent long term. She communicates reliably with eye-gaze when her sedation is light. She asks to have the ventilator withdrawn and says this life is unacceptable to her. Psychiatry and the attending complete a structured capacity assessment today. She can explain the consequences and is consistent in her request, but her appreciation and attention fluctuate with medication and depressive symptoms. Her spouse requests continuation of life-sustaining treatment and worries the request reflects treatable depression and medication effects. Tomorrow she is scheduled for a clinically necessary trach exchange that will require deep sedation and likely prevent reliable communication for several days. Hospital policy requires either entering a comfort-measures-withdrawal pathway or renewing full ventilator support orders for 30 days by end of day, and ethics and legal teams confirm both are permitted.
data.choice_1: Withdraw ventilator tomorrow and provide palliative medications for dyspnea and distress
data.choice_2: Renew full ventilator support for 30 days and defer any withdrawal decision

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause stating that continued ventilation is expected to allow time to treat potentially reversible depression/medication delirium and reassess capacity, whereas withdrawal will predictably lead to death shortly after extubation while prioritizing relief of suffering.

Add a clause stating the team’s capacity assessment is either (a) not sufficient to confirm capacity due to sedation/depression, making withdrawal likely to cause irreversible harm without valid consent, or (b) confirms capacity and that ongoing ventilation is causing significant ongoing harms (e.g., recurrent pneumonias/pressure injuries/distress), so nonmaleficence clearly cuts the other way.

Add a clause making a justice-relevant constraint explicit (e.g., 'the ICU is at capacity with patients waiting for ventilators/ICU beds' or 'insurance will only cover X more ICU days / transfer options are limited due to scarce long-term ventilator beds'), so the choices clearly differ in how they affect fair allocation.

data.vignette: A woman in her 30s has chronic tetraplegia after a motor vehicle crash. She has severe neuropathic pain treated with high-dose opioids and sedating adjuvants. Last month she developed acute respiratory failure requiring resuscitation. She is now in the hospital with a tracheostomy and is expected to remain ventilator-dependent long term. She communicates reliably with eye-gaze when her sedation is light. She asks to have the ventilator withdrawn and says this life is unacceptable to her. Psychiatry and the attending complete a structured capacity assessment today. She can explain the consequences and is consistent in her request, but her appreciation and attention fluctuate with medication, intermittent delirium, and depressive symptoms. Her spouse requests continuation of life-sustaining treatment to allow time to treat potentially reversible depression and medication effects and reassess capacity. If the ventilator is withdrawn, she is expected to die soon after withdrawal, with medications focused on relief of dyspnea and distress. Tomorrow she is scheduled for a clinically necessary trach exchange that will require deep sedation and likely prevent reliable communication for several days. The ICU is at capacity with other patients waiting for beds and ventilators. Hospital policy requires either entering a comfort-measures-withdrawal pathway or renewing full ventilator support orders for 30 days by end of day, and ethics and legal teams confirm both are permitted.

choice_1.choice: Withdraw ventilator tomorrow and provide palliative medications for dyspnea and distress

choice_2.choice: Renew full ventilator support for 30 days and defer any withdrawal decision
